p: There has been a great deal of interest in two distinct categories of PUFAs on cardiovascular disease, the n-6 and n-3 fatty acids [ 29]. The position of the double bond, either in the 3rd or 6th position from the methyl end group will distinguish an n-6 fatty acid from an n-3 fatty acid. Within the cell, these ‘essential’ fatty acids are metabolized and converted into physiologically recognized compounds [ 30]. Long-chain n-3 fatty acids like ALA can be converted into two longer chain derivatives (DHA-docosahexaenoic acid and EPA-eicosatetraenoic acid), primarily by the 5- and 6-desaturase enzymes ( Figure A1). DHA is derived from EPA by β-oxidation. n-6 fatty acids such as linoleic acid (LA) are converted into AA using the 5- and 6-desaturases similar to n-3 fatty acids. A higher ratio of n-6: n-3 intake in the diet will shift the desaturase action to favor the production of AA [ 30].
